elements.text: the imerge video is pretty eye-opening:

text: the basic idea is that if you’re combining A and B with a common ancestor, C, you just create the full grid of ways to get from C to A, B and everything in between

elements.text: the basic idea is that if you’re combining A and B with a common ancestor, C, you just create the full grid of ways to get from C to A, B and everything in between

text: which sounds insanely inefficient, but (a) most of them can be formed automatically, (b) some can be skipped, and (c) it allows resolving each conflict just once, at the point in the grid where it first arises, which is also the easiest context in which to resolve it
